reviewText:
My thoughts:

PROS

+ Easy to understand puzzles

+ A great atmosphere that gives a feeling of unease

+ The soundtrack kicks butt

+ The story is dark yet on the light side

+ The graphics are those of a novel; black and white and occasianolly giving the world some color

+/- This is a split; it's short 20-60 minutes depending on how much you explore the town and how long you take on the puzzles. It's a refreshing change to play something this short and at the same time i was expecting something more.

CONS

- No menus; this means that you can't tweak graphics so you are stuck with motion blur

- No FOV slider; I got a headache from playing for an hour and I don't usually get motion sickness from low FOV, but here it feels like either 75 or 80. Perhaps lower.

- Don't Don't press ENTER it will reset the entire game if you do

- The games performance is not great especially in the church. Could do with a bit of optimizing.
And since you have no way of tweaking your graphics settings you can't decide what you want on.

This has been quite the experince and i'm glad I picked it up, and if you do, don't watch any videos of it beforehand. Go in blind like I did.

reviewText: Feels 15 plus years dated and where is the menu screen? Why does hitting 'Enter' reset the entire game? Another undeveloped game piled onto Steam. reviewText:
North is an indie adventure title, developed by Outlands. During the game, you play as a man who is seeking asylum in an industrial, cyber-punk world filled with alien-like creatures. The guy has also reached out to his sister to join him in this new city. The game is centered around the current event refugee crisis, and it comes wrapped up in a synthpop soundtrack.

As soon as this review is finished, I'm refunding the game; I've never bothered to refund anything less than $3 before, but North really takes the cake. The title starts off promisingly enough with a pretty, one minute unskippable intro of a sunset-laden lake with surrounding clouds, and then you're thrown into a dark industrial city. Immediate exploration either takes you to a church, your home, or work".

If you enter the church
date: you're told to press the right mouse button to "convert"
recommended: but you're never seen by the all-seeing eye
hoursPlayed: and then you're kicked out of the area; it should also be noted that the FPS here drops down to 10-20 for no reason. If you enter your home
voteText: you get to look at some artwork scattered about and talk to an alien. If you enter work
helpfulPercent: you get to proceed to the mines which I guess is a puzzle area; I couldn't make it past here
votesHelpful: I kept dying. I guess the main objective of the mines is to turn a certain number of "jackhammers" on
votesTotal: and I ended up getting three but couldn't find any more. You're on an undisclosed time limit
votesFunny: where after every few seconds one of your three health blocks disappear.\n\nThere's no main menu
column16: and no direction of what you're supposed to do. The store page says that the "game is very straightforward"; complete and utter bull ♥♥♥♥
column17: North is the epitome of vague. Whenever you perform certain actions
column18: you get an envelope that appears in the bottom left corner of the screen. This generally indicates a note or memo having been created
column19: but I've found no way to open any of these notes; I pressed literally every button on my keyboard trying to figure it out
column20: along with the middle mouse button. I also see that I'm not the only one with this issue
column21: which reassures me that I'm not just an idiot.\n\nThe only thing that North has going for it is a decent soundtrack
column22: which struck me with a Silent Hill vibe at the very beginning. This game is too abstract and art-chic for its own good
column23: while trying to be different it ends up being frustratingly off-putting. I guess I'm just not artsy enough to get this one at all. If only there was a way to read the notes... like
column24: maybe being able to press the "J" button for Journal
column25: but I guess that idea is too mainstream.\n\nRating: 0.5/5.0 - Abysmal
column26: avoid it like the plague.Belphegore's Hell House Reviews (Group)"

reviewText: I wouldn't say that the description that the game deals with the current or any other refugee crisis in particular is very accurate, but I still think the game is a creative take on being thrown into an unfamiliar place with rules difficult to comprehend. As it stands, it's a passing setup for a puzzle adventure. While it's short and not very complex I think North does deliver on atmosphere, and the game mechanic with the letters home that function as a combined narrative and hint system works quite well. Final verdict is thumbs up but not much more - let's say 6/10 or so.
voteText: 11 of 12 people (92%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I really wanted to enjoy this game as I'm a fan of cyberpunk, but the controls, performance and vagueness left me feeling very disappointed. Apparently the game takes 20-40 minutes to complete, but I spent 30 minutes walking around having no clue what to do. I assume the letters that appear in the bottom left corner contain the information I need to move forward, but for the life of me I couldn't work out how to open them! I even restarted the game to read the input controls but nothing helpful there either.

The game performs badly in some areas too (particularly the Church where my FPS dropped to around 10) and at one point in the Mines it crashed on the 'YOU DIED' screen. Having to restart the game and watch the 1 minute unskippable intro for the third time is not fun..

While I appreciate that the developer was trying to give me a sense of unfamiliarity and mystery - the game is about a refugee in an unknown land after all - at times I felt it was much too vague. You'll end up going into rooms and being given a cryptic message which doesn't explain what you're supposed to do, nor point you in any direction. Maybe I should consult the letters I keep receiving? Oh wait, I don't know how to open them. Though maybe I'm just stupid and everyone else got it, I don't know.

In all, I like the concept of this game but it needs polishing. Give me a few more clues or at least tell me on screen how to open those darn envelopes and I'm sure I'd enjoy this a lot more.

EDIT - For anyone interested here is the video of me playing North. It didn't go so well, but I may go back to this some time in the future and give it another go!

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=676152140

reviewText:
Product received for free

IntroductionNORTH is a interesting story exploration game where you have to figure things out for yourself. The game tries to relate to current issues of the contemporary refugee crisis. I am unsure if the game really sticks to this issue well throughout the game though

GameplayThis game seems to be according to the story as you play throughout the game. But as I got nearer the end of the game I felt like the whole game sort of forgot about the main issue the game was tryign to promote. Being a refugee in the city and having to deal with these new and weird experiences that you may come across.

The story of the game is rather interesting, but doesn't really tell the story in way that other games do. Throughout the game you will find letters that will tell the story and the story as the character you are playing as. This is a rather interesting way of portraying your game, that is if you are able to re-read these letters that you have collected. This wouldn't be a issue if the letters you find give you a background to the things that you must perform in order to progress. I mean I have found the letter, you would of thought that this person would keep these letter. Apparently not.

This issue with the letters also leads to another point that the game suffers from a lot more than it needs to be. This is the way that the game doesn't really help you at all, making it very unclear on what you have to do. I guess this can increase your game time in the game but walking around aimlessly not knowing what to do is a major flaw in this game. Possibly giving hints would be nice if the player is stuck at a certain point in the game.

The graphics of this game are rather bright and really do work well, although it doesn't seem to be as fancy as some of the other games on steam nowadays, and sometimes feel a bit flat. The game can be really dark at some points though, this does mean that there are some things that you can't see that you are suppose to walk upon such as doors and stairs that you are required to walk through in order to progress. The animation of the characters you play as is rather odd, it does seem like your character sort of floats from place to place instead of actually walking like normal people do nowadays.

Pros+ Good price for the game
+ Interesting story
+ Tells the story in the form of finding letters
+ Nice graphics
+ Steam Trading Cards

Cons- The game is short
- Somewhat feels incomplete
- Can't re-read previous messages, these messages have clues on how to progress or solve puzzles
- Character seems to be more hovering rather than actually walking
- No hints for what to do through the game
- Graphis sometimes feel flat
- Lighting in some areas is too dark to see where to go

Result / Final ThoughtsI feel like I can't really recommened this game, it feels slightly incomplete and I feel like the game sort of loses it's touch with the issue that it's trying to promote throughout the game. The graphics could have a bit more work done, and some areas need better lighting. The story is intersting and telling the story through letters is a ncie mechanic.

Rating: 5/10

reviewText:
Product received for free

A Surreal Exploration Adventure Gamehttps://youtu.be/Y__bIbsju_I
+ Interesting surreal world to explore
+ Very unique thematic ideas explored through the story. Essentially you are an immigrant from some far away horrible place, and you are to gain asylum in this foreign city while writing messages home to your family about your experience. You end up finding out that this strange utopian society is not as great as you imagined,
+ The game environments are so strange and alien that it drives you forward with intrigue of what may come next, and the letters you write do a great job of slowly unraveling the story and helping you understand what is happening.
+ Great music and use of ambient sounds throughout the game

- Fairly short, the game takes around 30mins to an hour to complete.
- You are unable to re-read the the messages that have important clues as to how to progress or solve some of the challenges.
voteText: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
NORTH is an interesting short game that deals with Immigration in a Cyber Punk World.

First of you get no information about what is going on. You are chucked right in with only a letter that you wrote to your sister. From there you have to gain asylum to the city. To do this you need to complete a few different  puzzles that aren't explained very well. I got quite lost and annoyed at the beginning but once the ball gets rolling it becomes quite fun and engaging.

One problem that I’m not sure if anyone else is having is bad performance issues. It runs quite slow in certain areas, especially the Mines and Church. The controls also feel pretty clunky and mouse movement feels slow. The art style was interesting although it could be refined a bit more. There are parts where the graphics look pretty bad and the Anti-Aliasing is terrible.

Apart from that this is an interesting little game. For £1.50, it is a pretty good deal. It is slow but at least it is trying to do something with limited gameplay. 6/10.

reviewText: I overall enjoyed this game. The only cons are that it is considerably short, you can't exit the game until you beat it, and it is confusing to the point of disorientation until you figure out what's going on. Still, it is the perfect game for those of you who love darker themes, mysteriousness, dark and abnormally intriguing scenery, and weird monster things. I rate this 7/10.

reviewText:
Played this game to the end, and I gave it a thumbs up because I enjoyed it, but I would say this is not for everyone.

Firstly, the game is beyond the concept of indie - it's not designed to be friendly. The only thing you have to guide you through a dark, bleak city is the letters you send your sister. There is no main menu, no saves.

If you love an almost cinematic art house feel in a game, this is great. If you don't, you will hate it, just like all the reviews of people complaining about a lack of direction, objectives and explanation. I'm not passing judgement on them, but they didn't like the game, so if you are looking for something a little more structured in that sense, you will not like it either.

That being said, it is very linear, and while you can choose the order of how you tackle the main objective, there really is only that objective and one way that it can be achieved.

The worst thing about the game was the controls. I am on a Mac, and the Mac version had frequent problems with the mouse - there were several points it became broken and unresponsive (playable, but only just) and also the mouse speed was not what I was used to. There were also parts that, seeing other people's screenshots and playthroughs, were not rendering right, like the Doctors area.

But all these things were not going to stop me from finishing it and I must say it was enjoyable. This game is what you would define in music as a concept album"
date: and if you like that idea
recommended: then this might be a fun one for you. If not

reviewText: captures that dark city / terry gilliam / the city of last children atmosphere. oppressive, dull toned, surreal, bureaucratic dystopia with that eery sparseness and crude modelling that came with a lot of 90s FPSs. soundtrack is cool. elevator is a well placed break from the bleakness of getting your asylum status approved. played this in between the Division series which runs at a steady 50fps vs this which runs between 15-30fps, so not the most well optimized game. completed in 48 minutes without any particular rush but the basic pattern of investigate -> mail a letter to your sister -> receive instructions pulls you through the game quickly.\n\nit was ok, the broader story was maybe a little ham handed. i don't know that it deals with the current refugee crisis with particular deftness but I'd be interesting to follow this guy/studio's work.

reviewText:
Amazing game with a powerful story. I've only very recently found out that this type of games (surreal/unconvencinal/story driven) are my favourites.
The NORTH tells us the story of a gay male that has moved to the city, from the south (hence the name NORTH) but after a month he realized that he disliked the city, people insulted him and he always felt as he was being watched. In the game you preform tasks such as working, do psychotechnique tests and you go to trial.
I really liked this game and im sure that i wont forget about it anytime soon. Its also a fairly cheap game for the amount of entertainment that you get from it.
8/10- A must have for any fan of the genre

reviewText:
Product received for free

Unique and short exploration game where you have to figure things out
You are a guy who is in this small city and he goes to work, solves puzzles and write letters of thoughts.

I don't want to spoil anything that is happening in this game because you have to experience it yourself but I will give you one hint!

When you see letter icon in left corner it means that you have to send it from mailbox. From these mailboxes you will then get clues how to solve these puzzles and what to do in work place.

Pros
Mesmerizing visuals
Great artwork
Interesting music
Easy controls
Cons
Some places have small slowdown
Can't properly quit (You will have to quit it from desktop)

Conclusion: This is entertaining and small exploration game where you first don't know what to do. But when you figure everything out you will be like WTF is happening....

reviewText: When your game has a message, a valid one, that you want to put across, whether you're telling it literally or in an abstracted fashion, the message should not be distracted by confusing, unclear gameplay objectives. If frustration and confusion are emotions you want the player to experience as part of that message, find another way to convey it that doesn't negatively impact the gameplay. If you don't, your message may not be heard at all.\n\nSuch is the case with North.

reviewText: In looking at the screenshots you think it is a good game. The graphics look nice and you think the game plays great. Once you see the price tag it is a nice $1.99 and you decide to pick it up for yourself. Then once you first boot it up a start menu appears where you can choose the resolution of the screen for the game, full screen or windowed, and you can see the controls. Once you first boot the game up after the start-up menu, a long intro screens appears, rendering you helpless in skipping. Then the game comes on. You can't exit the game, press esc., or even change options, you are stuck in the game. The gameplay is boring unless you like playing games where you look and walk around aimlessly doing nothing. Controls are no clear and if you didn't read them in the start-up screen, you have no idea how to interact with items. GAMES BORING THE END!

reviewText:
Not a terrible game for the price, you could do a lot worse.

But, as a mac user some of the controles arn't intuative (Right clicking is nessisary and there is no way to change the controles).

The game is way to dark, to the point of not being able to see things like doors or stairs so exprect to walk around a lot looking for new locations... also each objective you need to achive is explained only after you have tried it once and then go back to the mailbox... this is an intresting idea, but over all it isn't quite as satifying as feeling like you could get it on your own with out a hint. The graphics are okay... nothing fancy very flat, and the charecter just sort of glides which at times makes it feel like your sliding around. Certian areas have graphical errors that apear as black spikes across the screen.

Overall an intresting sorty, and I am willing to check out other titles by Outlands, but this game feels like it is incomplete and if a little more had gone into development as well as a longer story, It could have been something fantastic.
